text: The thick rhyolite lava flows and extensive ash deposits in and around Yellowstone National Park are well-known exceptions to this generalization.
In contrast to granite, which is widely distributed as large intrusive masses, rhyolite deposits are less common and generally less voluminous.
Rhyolite Rhyolite is the fine-grained equivalent of granite and, like granite, is composed essentially of the light-colored silicates .
Rhyolite is fine-grained and frequently contains glass fragments and voids, indicating that it cooled rapidly in a surface, or near-surface, environment.
These specimens contain elongated feldspar crystals a few centimeters in length that are scattered among smaller crystals of quartz and amphibole .
Although the dark components generally make up less than 10 percent of most granites, dark minerals appear to be more prominent than their percentage indicates.
However, when composed of dark pink feldspar grains, granite can exhibit a reddish color.
This fact accounts for its color, which is usually buff to pink or occasionally light gray.
small amounts of dark silicates, particularly biotite and amphibole, and sometimes muscovite.
At a distance, most granitic rocks appear gray in color .
In addition, some granites have a porphyritic texture.
